RT @RepJayapal Yesterday, I called for fines to be levied on every Member who cruelly and recklessly refuses to wear a mask in the Capitol during a raging pandemic.
 
Tonight, the House of Representatives voted to adopt this commonsense public health guideline. It must be enforced immediately!

Impeach. https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1349029953174700033 QT @nytimes Breaking News: President Trump showed no contrition for inciting the deadly riot at the Capitol, saying his remarks beforehand were “totally appropriate” and that the effort by Congress to impeach and convict him was “causing tremendous anger.”
https://trib.al/RV5BxhZ

I look forward to continuing to fight for my conservative principles and policies that benefit the great people of my district and to doing everything I can to bring our country together. #ks02 #ksleg

The Electoral College has spoken; it is time for our country to turn the page. There will be a peaceful transfer of power on January 20th when President-elect Biden is sworn in, just as our nation has always done since our founding.
Instead, Democrats are choosing to ram through a divisive impeachment while simultaneously mobilizing Big Tech to silence and demonize conservatives.
The focus should be on bringing the criminals that broke into the Capitol to justice and conducting a bipartisan investigation into the security breakdown.
I intend to vote no by proxy on both the 25th Amendment resolution and Article of Impeachment. Please read my full statement below:

3/3 I will not oversee the slow decline of our nation, but instead will work to ensure a bright future for our children and grandchildren. We must pray for and build a better, stronger America and keep believing that our greatest days are yet to come. #KS01

2/3 I will not be voting to support impeachment.  Impeachment will only lead to further division in our great nation and add to the political chaos. We will have a peaceful transition of power on January 20th.

1/3 America is the greatest country the world has ever known. We face many challenges and seem more divided as a nation right now than at any other time during my life. As your Congressman, I am committed to finding ways to come together and move forward.

Thank you to the @CapitolPolice for everything you do to protect us! Happy to add to the voices of "Thanks". THANK YOU to everyone who joined our tele-town hall tonight! I also thank our amazing panelists: Dr. Anthone, Dr. Pour, Sara Schram, & Angela Ling from Douglas & Sarpy Co. Health Depts for sharing their medical expertise and for addressing Nebraska’s #COVID vaccination plans.

Rep. Bacon: This has been the worst pandemic in 102 years, but there’s light at the end of the tunnel. We will win this battle with the vaccine. #OperationWarpSpeed has been vital in the success of these vaccine.

Q: Why doesn’t the fed gov distribute more funding for the distribution:
A: Dr. Anthone: The federal gov has been very helpful in giving us in distribution & money for medical equipment.
A: Rep. Bacon—We put nearly $8 Billion in the last package for #COVID distribution.

Q: Will there be a vaccine free of aborted fetal cells?
A: Dr. Anthone—The Pfizer and Moderna vaccine do NOT have aborted fetal cells in the vaccine. 
A: Rep. Bacon—We’ve had Committee hearings on this topic. Here in the U.S. that’s not the issue.

Q: What if you have a reaction to the vaccine?
Dr. Anthone & Dr. Pour—Talk to your health care provider […] If more severe, have that discussion with your primary doctor. They are the best resource.

Q: Safety concerns for those with autoimmune disease?
A: Dr. Anthone & Dr. Pour— Still recommended to get the vaccine.

Q: Approx. notification to get the vaccine & where?
A: Will be offered through different healthcare systems/providers.
A: Our system will feed into the fed system. There will be plenty of opportunities to go to your pharmacies, especially w/ more vaccines in the works.
Important websites to visit: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/default.aspx https://www.douglascountyhealth.com https://www.sarpycasshealthdepartment.org

@michell48971532 Dept. Press Sec. here: To clarify, Dr. Pour was explaining the need to give everyone, including health care workers, the opportunity to receive it. I encourage you to join us LIVE to listen to the town hall in its entirety.

Dr. Pour: This isn't an easy planning process. We're hoping as time goes on this will become more regular […] Douglas Co. has a great website with information. […] We want to make sure everyone has the opportunity to get the vaccine [...] we are not wasting one single dose.

Dr. Pour: We’ve seen a decrease in our cases in Douglas Co, fewer people hospitalized [...] still have a way to go. We’ve had more than 150 deaths in Nov & a little over 100 in Dec […] We need the cooperation of everyone in this community, we must vaccinate health care workers.

Angela Ling: We’ve been receiving nearly 11,000+ doses of each vaccine each week for the first dose […] The federal government control the second dose. […] We definitely still have more work to do to get more people vaccinated [...] People are moving inventories up as well.

Dr. Anthone: We were very fortunate to see the rate of hospitalizations decline […] we’ve been on calls with the #OperationWarpSpeed team & WH to know when our state would get vaccines […] 3 days later that Pfizer vaccine was distributed.

RepBacon: The Problem Solvers Caucus (25Rs & 25Ds) and I drafted the bipartisan #COVID relief bill to add more funding for the unemployment [...] our goal was to keep people employed. We put money towards our K-12 schools, child care providers, low income housing & live venues.

My hope for this new Congress and the post Trump era is perhaps there will be less less sensationalizing, less score settling. Maybe we can do the quiet & hard work of passing policies to improve people’s lives, to recognize their suffering, and to build a multiracial democracy.

I still believe the second Iraq war was a huge blunder. I started my political activism because of that. But it doesn’t make one less principled, less willing to change policy, if one debates and discusses issues searching to persuade and find some common ground.

When I told @Liz_Cheney that her father spoke in Philadelphia to the World Affairs Council at the height of the Gulf war when I was in 10th grade and encouraged young people to go into public service, she sent me a signed book she and her father had written.

.@Liz_Cheney and I were in the same class. We have had vigorous debates on foreign policy and probably see the world completely differently on so many of those issues. But she has always been civil on the Armed Services Committee, even when deeply opposed to my views.

It’s easy to demonize. It’s much harder to search for some common humanity. I genuinely believe that’s what @JoeBiden aspires for this nation. It’s not about whether impeachment takes up the first few weeks or not. It’s about how we treat each other as colleagues, as Americans.

Remember, there are many Republican members who are receiving threats and who were targets of the mob as well. There are people who I vehemently disagree with on the election, but may share views on getting us out of war or helping rural America or even the global poor.

There has to be accountability for R colleagues who incited rioters and fines for not wearing masks. But let us not write off constituencies & create an impression that we live in constant fear of each other. We don’t. Today I rode in elevators & spoke to many Rs I disagree with.

Thread: I appreciate the messaged tonight concerned about my safety going on the floor. I write this not to score points, but as an American concerned for our nation. I still believe in the decency of the vast majority of Americans & the possibility of dialogue with colleagues.

RT @AndrewSolender Top House Dem committee chairs: "Based on today’s briefing, we have grave concerns about ongoing and violent threats to our democracy." http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Erj6Ir9WMAIYDzO.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Erj6I55W4AE2jJ8.jpg

We demand full accountability not only to hold those perpetrators responsible, but to send a strong signal that future seditious activity will not be tolerated and will be met with the full force of the law.

Officials in today’s briefing confirmed that they will prosecute every individual associated with this act, including anyone who entered restricted areas outside the Capitol, as well as those who breached the Capitol itself.
This was an attempted coup to derail our Constitutional process and intimidate our duly elected leaders through violence.
This is a moment when our entire national security and law enforcement apparatus must be working in complete lockstep.  This was not a peaceful protest that got out of hand.
We are also troubled by reports about warnings received by law enforcement authorities and the actions taken to share those warnings and respond to them prior to the attack.
We will not discuss specific security measures under consideration, but we will be working closely with our leadership in Congress and all appropriate federal, state, and local authorities.

Based on today’s briefing, we have grave concerns about ongoing and violent threats to our democracy.  It is clear that more must be done to preempt, penetrate, and prevent deadly and seditious assaults by domestic violent extremists in the days ahead.

9/ Biden can, and should, reverse the designation on day one. It's a no brainer. But the damage will be lasting. Some humanitarian groups may be spooked out of Yemen. The Houthis will be pushed to Iran. Peace negotiations will be less likely. A disaster of our own making.

8/ Finally, there's no upside. At all. Pompeo says it will send the Houthis a message. What? The State Dept. briefing today was a disaster. They had no answers for how this will drive Houthis to the negotiating table. No answers for how to prevent starvation.

7/ Gets worse. A Houthi controlled rotting oil tanker sits right off the coast of the country's most important port. Soon, it will start leaking oil, or worse, explode, making the Beirut blast look like child's play. Houthis will now be much less willing to deal with UN on this.

6/ And in that corner is Iran. At the start of the war, there was a loose relationship between the Houthis and Iran. As the war has dragged, the alliance has grown stronger. Now, it cements. The Iran-skeptic wing of the Houthis is now pushed into Iran's waiting arms. Disaster.

5/ Gets worse. The only way to achieve a political settlement is for the U.S. and the UN to broker a settlement between Houthis and the Saudis. But by law, the U.S. can't talk to terrorist groups, and frankly, the Houthis won't talk now anyway. They've been backed into a corner.

5/ Gets worse. Commercial food importers will not send food into the same areas. Yemen imports almost all its food. So the designation is essentially a death sentence for millions. No humanitarian food. No commercial food.

4/ Only food aid keeps people alive in Yemen. But humanitarian organizations can't work in areas of countries controlled by terrorist organizations. Now, these programs will shut down in areas of Yemen controlled by the Houthis.

3/ The Houthis are bad guys. They target civilians. They steal food aid. But they aren't what we would traditionally consider a "terrorist group". They are using barbaric tactics in the conduct of war. But so are the Saudis. They intentionally target civilians too.

2/ A civil war has been raging in Yemen since 2014. Saudi Arabia and the U.S. are on one side. The rebel Houthi tribe and Iran on the other. It has caused a humanitarian crisis - the worst in the world. 100,000 children have died of starvation or disease. 16m are malnourished.

@hiimcubes If the required threshold of votes isn’t met, the vote fails - even if it’s bc people didn’t show up or voted present. You have to bring it up for another vote again to pass it.

@blakemoris A few reasons:

Sometimes it’s to get members on the record, so ppl can’t make excuses later.

Sometimes these votes create real political pressure that forces developments.

Sometimes we vote for the historical record - to let future generations know we did everything we could.

@shapscott @PramilaJayapal We added a rule which allows members impacted by COVID to vote by proxy on the House floor.

@eleanor_5678 It’s kind of confusing but basically House floor votes aren’t just the bill you want to vote on. The RULE defines how the legislation is packaged and debated prior to voting.

For example, the RULE we just voted on includes a provision that allows us to criticize Trump in debate.

@eleanor_5678 Sure! Basically before you have any vote on legislation, we often need a procedural vote 1st.

Today the BIG vote is on a RESOLUTION, (think of this as a Congressional message). The RESOLUTION is telling Mike Pence to invoke the 25th amendment. We just voted on the RULE for that.
